revision.comment: Update link after RM, replaced: [[face-to-face]] → [[Face-to-face (philosophy)|face-to-face]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[Emmanuel Levinas]], in an attempt to overcome a certain naivety within his exploration of ethics as given in what he describes as the [[Face-to-face (philosophy)|face-to-face]] encounter, attempts to introduce language into what had only been a "picture" of such an encounter. He distinguishes between '''The saying''' of something and what it is that is said during the talk, '''The said'''.
== Ethics and language ==
=== The Saying === The Saying relates to an irreducible exposure to the other. The saying makes the self-exposure of sincerity possible, a way of giving everything, of not holding secrets, of complete generosity. One is corrupted into, learns or decides, to lie, to simulate, to dissimulate, to ignore and remain politically or economically silent.
=== The Said === The said, on the other hand, refers to the intelligibility and reference of what is communicated or transferred, it can be subjected to the closure truth as total [[metaphysics of presence|presence]], it is associated with [[ontology]] (i.e., philosophy and science).
::Man can give himself in saying to the point of poetry - or he can withdraw into the non-saying of lies. Language as saying is an ethical openness to the other; as that which is said - reduced to a fixed identity or synchronized presence - it is an ontological closure of the other.’ <ref>Kearney, Richard. "Dialogues with contemporary continental thinkers", Manchester: MUP, 1984</ref>
The complication Levinas introduces into his analysis of the face-to-face gives his ethics a further reach toward the kind of universalist ethics of a [[humanism]]:
::One can see an image of destitution and choose a logic in which to ignore it, one can hear the cry, the plea, and be summoned to the logic of another person.
== Notes == <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Saying}} [[Category:Philosophical concepts]]

{{subspeciesbox | name = Ugandan kob | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = {{IUCN2008|assessor=Anderson, M.|assessor2=Mills, G.|last-assessor-amp=yes|year=2008|id=11043|title=Kobus kob ssp. thomasi|downloaded=22 March 2009}} Database entry includes a brief justification of why this species is of least concern | image = Ugandan kob (Kobus kob thomasi) male.jpg | image_caption = Male | image2 = Ugandan kobs (Kobus kob thomasi) female and calf.jpg | image2_caption = Female and calf
both at [[Semliki Wildlife Reserve]], [[Uganda]] | genus = Kobus | species = kob | subspecies = thomasi | authority = ([[Philip Sclater|Sclater]], 1864) }} The '''Ugandan kob''' (''Kobus kob thomasi'') is a [[subspecies]] of the [[kob]], a type of [[antelope]] found in [[sub-Saharan Africa]] in [[South Sudan]], [[Uganda]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], and [[Ethiopia]]. It is normally reddish-brown, in which it differs from other kob subspecies. A Ugandan kob appears on the [[coat of arms of Uganda]]. The Ugandan kob is sometimes alternatively classified into the [[subgenus]] ''[[Adenota]]''. References are sometimes made to it by the [[Dutch language|Dutch]] name of '''Oeganda-waterbok'''. Ugandan kobs (Kobus kob thomasi) females and males.jpg|females and males grazing
Uganda Ugandan kobs (Kobus kob thomasi).jpg|two males
Uganda Ugandan kob (Kobus kob thomasi) male head.jpg|head of a male
Uganda Ugandan kobs (Kobus kob thomasi) males fighting composite.jpg|males fighting
Uganda Ugandan kobs (Kobus kob thomasi) mating ritual composite.jpg|mating ritual
Uganda == Further reading == ''[[Kob|Kobus kob]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} * DuVal, E. 2000. "[http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/site/accounts/information/Kobus_kob.html Kobus kob"] (On-line), Animal Diversity Web. Accessed 21 September 2006. {{Taxonbar|from=Q5419779}} {{DEFAULTSORT:kob, Ugandan}} [[Category:Marsh antelopes]] [[Category:Mammals of Uganda]] [[Category:National symbols of Uganda]] [[Category:Mammals described in 1864|Ugandan kob]] [[Category:Subspecies]] {{eventoedungulate-stub}}

revision.comment: nothing inherently political (left or right) or "alternative scene" (whatever that means) - add source for proof if so.
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date = July 2016}} [[File:2014-06-02 Sudan Flüchtlinge Protest gegen Abschiebung, Weißekreuzplatz Hannover, (07) Getränke an der Volxküche.jpg|thumb|A Volxküche event in Germany, 2014]] '''VolxKuche'''/'''VolxKüche''' ('''VoKu'''/'''VoKü'''), '''peoples kitchen''', '''free supper club''' or '''kitchen for all''', are names used for a weekly or regularly occurring group cooking event, at which the meal is served free of charge or at cost. The name derives from the German expression "people's kitchen" (soup kitchen), as a secular counterpart of the Christian [[soup kitchen]].
Volxküchen are found usually in collective and/or self-managed arrangements (pubs, information stores, youth centers or autonomous centers) with politically left self-identity. In general at least one vegetarian meal is offered, frequently also vegan food. Often soon to be [[Shelf life|expired]] ingredients are obtained at cost, or donated by food banks, food manufacturers or community gardens.<ref name="VokuCookbook">{{Cite book | author = Hannabambel Tavern Collective | title = Das Volxküchen-Kochbuch | year = 2011 | ISBN = 978-3-86569-081-4 | publisher=Alibri Verlag}}</ref><ref name="VokudeLuxe">{{Cite book | author = Hannabambel Tavern Collective | title = Volxküche De Luxe | year = 2011 | ISBN = 978-3-86569-082-1 | publisher=Alibri Verlag}}</ref>
==History== The Volxküche in the current sense arose in the European squatter scene of the early 1980s.
==English spelling and pronunciation== The spelling of Volxküche occurred as an expression of anti-nationalism. Historically nationalism had used the term "[[Volk (German word)|Volk]]/Volks" with negative consequences. This use was a rejection of the negative connotation which had the intention of "excluding" many groups of German society. It is at the same time a funny self-willed expression of the anarchistic and/or autonomous scene.
In the US the word is spelled without an umlaut, and pronounced like "folks coo heh". The alternate German spelling Volkskueche (Volksküche) was intentionally not used.
== US locations == A 'Free Supper Club" in San Francisco, held twice a month as of 2013, is calling itself ''Volxkuche''. Besides a free dinner, performances, film and community are provided.<ref>VokuSF Website: http://www.vokusf.org/</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Hunger relief}} * [[Food Not Bombs]] * [[Freegan]] * [[Homeless ministry]] * [[List of supper clubs]] ==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:VolxKuche}} [[Category:Giving]] [[Category:Poverty activism]] [[Category:Restaurants by type]] [[Category:Free meals]] [[Category:Hunger relief organizations]] [[Category:Soup kitchens]] [[Category:Supper clubs]]

revision.comment: /* Wabi-sabi in Japanese arts */ simplify heading
revision.text:
{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} {{Expand Japanese|わび・さび|date=October 2018}} [[File:RyoanJi-Dry garden.jpg|thumb|[[Zen garden]] of [[Ryōan-ji]]. It was built during the [[Higashiyama period]]. The clay wall, which is stained by age with subtle brown and orange tones, reflects ''sabi'', and the rock garden ''wabi''.<ref>森神逍遥 『侘び然び幽玄のこころ』桜の花出版、2015年 Morigami Shouyo,"Wabi sabi yugen no kokoro : seiyo tetsugaku o koeru joi ishiki" (Japanese) {{ISBN|978-4434201424}}</ref>]] [[Image:2002 kenrokuen hanami 0123.jpg|thumb|right|A Japanese tea house which reflects the wabi-sabi aesthetic in [[Kenroku-en]] (兼六園) Garden]] [[Image:Black Raku Tea Bowl.jpg|thumb|right|Wabi-sabi tea bowl, [[Azuchi-Momoyama period]], 16th century]]
In traditional [[Japanese aesthetics]], {{nihongo||[[wikt:侘|侘]][[wikt:寂|寂]]|'''wabi-sabi'''}} is a [[world view]] centered on the acceptance of [[wikt:transience|transience]] and imperfection.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nobleharbor.com/tea/chado/WhatIsWabi-Sabi.htm|title=What Is Wabi-Sabi?|website=nobleharbor.com|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref> The aesthetic is sometimes described as one of beauty that is "imperfect, impermanent, and incomplete".<ref name=Koren/> It is a concept derived from the [[Buddhist]] teaching of the {{nihongo|[[three marks of existence]]|三法印|sanbōin}}, specifically {{nihongo|[[impermanence]]|無常|mujō}}, {{nihongo|[[dukkha|suffering]]|苦|ku}} and {{nihongo|[[śūnyatā|emptiness or absence of self-nature]]|空|kū}}.
Characteristics of the ''wabi-sabi'' aesthetic include [[asymmetry]], roughness, [[simplicity]], economy, austerity, modesty, [[intimacy]], and appreciation of the ingenuous integrity of natural objects and processes.
==Description== According to [[Leonard Koren]], ''wabi-sabi'' can be defined as "the most conspicuous and characteristic feature of traditional Japanese beauty and it occupies roughly the same position in the Japanese [[wiktionary:pantheon|pantheon]] of aesthetic values as do the [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] ideals of [[beauty]] and perfection in the far West."<ref name=Koren/> Whereas Andrew Juniper notes that "If an object or expression can bring about, within us, a sense of serene melancholy and a spiritual longing, then that object could be said to be wabi-sabi."<ref name=Juniper>{{cite book |last=Juniper |first=Andrew |title=Wabi Sabi: The Japanese Art of Impermanence | publisher=Tuttle Publishing | year=2003 | isbn=0-8048-3482-2}}</ref> For Richard Powell, "Wabi-sabi nurtures all that is authentic by acknowledging three simple realities: nothing lasts, nothing is finished, and nothing is perfect."<ref name=Powell>{{cite book | author=Powell, Richard R. | title=Wabi Sabi Simple | publisher=Adams Media | year=2004 | isbn=1-59337-178-0}}</ref>
The words ''wabi'' and ''sabi'' do not translate easily. ''Wabi'' originally referred to the loneliness of living in nature, remote from society; ''sabi'' meant "chill", "lean" or "withered". Around the 14th century these meanings began to change, taking on more positive connotations.<ref name=Koren>{{cite book |last=Koren |first=Leonard |title=Wabi-Sabi for Artists, Designers, Poets and Philosophers |publisher=Stone Bridge Press |year=1994 |isbn=1-880656-12-4}}</ref> ''Wabi'' now connotes rustic simplicity, freshness or quietness, and can be applied to both natural and human-made objects, or understated elegance. It can also refer to quirks and anomalies arising from the process of construction, which add uniqueness and elegance to the object. ''Sabi'' is beauty or serenity that comes with age, when the life of the object and its impermanence are evidenced in its [[patina]] and wear, or in any visible repairs.
After centuries of incorporating artistic and Buddhist influences from China, wabi-sabi eventually evolved into a distinctly Japanese ideal. Over time, the meanings of ''wabi'' and ''sabi'' shifted to become more lighthearted and hopeful. Around 700 years ago, particularly among the Japanese nobility, understanding emptiness and imperfection was honored as tantamount to the first step to [[satori]], or enlightenment. In today's Japan, the meaning of wabi-sabi is often condensed to "wisdom in natural simplicity". In art books, it is typically defined as "flawed beauty".<ref>Gold, Taro. (2004) [[Taro Gold]]'s ''Living Wabi Sabi'' (Kansas City: [[Andrews McMeel Publishing]], {{ISBN|0-7407-3960-3}}), pp. 20–21.</ref>
From an engineering or design point of view, ''wabi'' may be interpreted as the imperfect quality of any object, due to inevitable limitations in design and construction/manufacture especially with respect to unpredictable or changing usage conditions; then ''sabi'' could be interpreted as the aspect of imperfect reliability, or limited mortality of any object, hence the phonological and etymological connection with the Japanese word sabi, {{nihongo|to rust|錆||also pronounced ''sabi''}}. Although the [[kanji]] characters for "rust" is not the same {{nihongo||寂|sabi}} in ''wabi-sabi'', the original spoken word (pre-kanji, ''[[yamato-kotoba]]'') is believed to be one and the same.<ref>錆びをめぐる話題, 井上勝也, 裳華房, 1994</ref><ref>[http://www2.memenet.or.jp/kinugawa/sabi/00121.htm さびの文字] on the Kinugawa Chain Mfg. Co. Ltd website</ref> [[File:Contemporary wabi-sabi tea bowl.jpg|left|thumb|Modern tea vessel made in the ''wabi-sabi'' style]] A good example of this embodiment may be seen in certain styles of Japanese pottery. In the [[Japanese tea ceremony]], the pottery items used are often rustic and simple-looking, e.g. [[Hagi ware]], with shapes that are not quite symmetrical, and colors or textures that appear to emphasize an unrefined or simple style. In fact, it is up to the knowledge and observational ability of the participant to notice and discern the hidden signs of a truly excellent design or [[Ceramic glaze|glaze]] (akin to the appearance of a diamond in the rough). This may be interpreted as a kind of wabi-sabi aesthetic, further confirmed by the way the colour of glazed items is known to change over time as hot water is repeatedly poured into them (''sabi'') and the fact that tea bowls are often deliberately chipped or nicked at the bottom (''wabi''), which serves as a kind of signature of the ''Hagi-yaki'' style.
''Wabi'' and ''sabi'' both suggest sentiments of desolation and solitude. In the [[Mahayana Buddhist]] view of the universe, these may be viewed as positive characteristics, representing liberation from a material world and [[transcendence (philosophy)|transcendence]] to a simpler life. Mahayana philosophy itself, however, warns that genuine understanding cannot be achieved through words or language, so accepting wabi-sabi on nonverbal terms may be the most appropriate approach. Simon Brown<ref name="Brown">{{cite book | author=Brown, Simon | title=Practical Wabi Sabi | publisher=Carroll & Brown |year=2007 | isbn=1-904760-55-4}}</ref> notes that wabi-sabi describes a means whereby students can learn to live life through the senses and better engage in life as it happens, rather than be caught up in unnecessary thoughts. In this sense wabi-sabi is the material representation of Zen Buddhism. The idea is that being surrounded by natural, changing, unique objects helps us connect to our real world and escape potentially stressful distractions.
In one sense wabi-sabi is a training whereby the student of wabi-sabi learns to find the most basic, natural objects interesting, fascinating and beautiful. Fading autumn leaves would be an example. Wabi-sabi can change our perception of the world to the extent that a chip or crack in a vase makes it more interesting and gives the object greater meditative value. Similarly materials that age such as bare wood, paper and fabric become more interesting as they exhibit changes that can be observed over time.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}
The ''wabi'' and ''sabi'' concepts are religious in origin, but actual usage of the words in Japanese is often quite casual because of the [[syncretic]] nature of Japanese belief.
==In Japanese arts== Many [[Japanese art]]s over the past thousand years have been influenced by [[Zen]] and [[Mahayana]] philosophy, particularly acceptance and contemplation of the imperfection, constant [[flux]] and [[impermanence]] of all things. Such arts can exemplify a wabi-sabi aesthetic. Examples include: * [[Honkyoku]] (traditional [[shakuhachi]] music of wandering Zen monks) * [[Ikebana]] (flower arrangement) * [[Bonsai]] design features such as snags, deadwood and hollow trunks highlight passage of time and natural cycles. Bonsai are often displayed in fall color or after they have shed leaves seasonally, to admire their bare branches. * [[Japanese garden]]s, [[Zen garden]]s (tray gardens) * [[Japanese poetry]] * [[Japanese pottery]], [[Hagi ware]], [[Raku ware]] * [[Japanese tea ceremony]]
A contemporary Japanese appraisal of this concept is found in the influential essay ''[[In Praise of Shadows]]'' by [[Jun'ichirō Tanizaki]].
==Western use== Designer [[Leonard Koren]] (born 1948) in 1994 published ''Wabi-Sabi for Artists, Designers, Poets & Philosophers''<ref name=Koren/> as an examination of wabi-sabi, contrasting it with Western ideals of beauty. According to Penelope Green, Koren's book subsequently "became a talking point for a wasteful culture intent on penitence and a touchstone for designers of all stripes."<ref name=Green>{{cite web|last=Green|first=Penelope|title=An Idiosyncratic Designer, a Serene New Home|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/23/garden/23leonard.html|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2012-09-25}}</ref>
Potter [[Bernard Leach]] (1887–1979) was deeply influenced by Japanese aesthetics and techniques and founded an influential European aesthetic movement which also included Dame [[Lucy Rie]] and [[Hans Coper]].
Some [[haiku in English]] adapt the wabi-sabi aesthetic, with spare, minimalist poems that evoke loneliness and transience,{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} such as [[Nick Virgilio]]'s "autumn twilight:/ the wreath on the door/ lifts in the wind".<ref>[[Cor van den Heuvel]], editor. ''The Haiku Anthology''. Fireside, 1986. {{ISBN|0671628372}} p285</ref>
The work of American artist [[John Connell]] (born 1940) is centered on the idea of wabi.<ref>Hess Art Collection, Hatje Cantz, 2010</ref>
Former [[Stuckist]] artist and [[remodernist film]]maker [[Jesse Richards]] (born 1975) employs it in nearly all of his work, along with [[mono no aware]].
During the 1990s the concept was borrowed by computer software developers and employed in [[Agile programming]] and [[Wiki]] to describe acceptance of the state of ongoing imperfection that is the product of these methods.<ref>{{cite web | title = Wabi Sabi | url = http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?WabiSabi | accessdate = 2006-11-19 }}</ref>
On 16 March 2009, [[Marcel Theroux]] presented "In Search of Wabi Sabi" on [[BBC Four]] as part of the channel's ''Hidden Japan'' season of programming. Theroux traveled throughout Japan trying to understand the aesthetic tastes of its people, beginning by comically enacting a challenge from the book ''Living Wabi Sabi'' by [[Taro Gold]] to "ask people on a Tokyo street to describe Wabi Sabi." Theroux showed that, just as Gold predicted, "they will likely give you a polite shrug and explain that Wabi Sabi is simply unexplainable." <ref>Gold, Taro. (2004) [[Taro Gold]]'s ''Living Wabi Sabi'' (Kansas City: [[Andrews McMeel Publishing]], {{ISBN|0-7407-3960-3}}), p. 6.</ref>
[[Jack Dorsey]], the billionaire founder of [[Twitter]] and [[Square, Inc.|Square]], promotes the Wabi-sabi philosophy of design.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Many Sides of Jack Dorsey | url = https://www.wired.com/business/2012/06/ff_dorsey/ | first = Steven | last = Levy | date = June 22, 2012 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | accessdate = 2013-05-24 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Clinamen]] * [[Higashiyama Bunka]] in [[Muromachi period]] * [[iki (aesthetic ideal)|Iki]] (a Japanese aesthetic ideal) * [[Mono no aware]] * [[Shibui]] * [[Teaism]] * [[Wabi-cha]] * [[Kintsugi]] (also known as Kintsukuroi)
==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book | author=Crowley, James and Sandra | title=Wabi Sabi Style | publisher=Gibbs Smith, Publisher | year=2001 | isbn=1-58685-753-3}} * {{cite book | author=Koren, Leonard | title=Wabi-Sabi for Artists, Designers, Poets & Philosophers | location=Point Reyes, CA | publisher=Imperfect Publishing | year=2008 | isbn=978-0-9814846-0-0}} * {{cite book | author=Suzuki, Daisetz T. | title=Zen and Japanese Culture | chapter=Chapter 2: General Remarks on Japanese Art Culture | publisher=MJF Books | location= New York | year=1959 | pages=19–38 | isbn=1-56731-124-5}} * Tierney, Lennox (1999), ''Wabi Sabi'', Layton, Utah: Gibbs Smith, Publisher. {{ISBN|0-87905-849-8}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z2P8z7kYJW0 In Search of Wabi Sabi] with [[Marcel Theroux]]
{{Japanese social terms}} {{Japanese architectural elements}}

{{short description|Leopard population in Zanzibar}} {{subspeciesbox | name = Zanzibar leopard | image = Zanzibar Leopard 2.JPG | image_caption = Mounted specimen in the Zanzibar Museum <!-- | status of SUBspecies is not assessed in IUCN Red List |status_system = |status_ref = --> | genus = Panthera | species = pardus | species_link = Leopard | subspecies = pardus | authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]]) | synonyms = formerly ''P. p. adersi''<ref name="Pocock1932"/> }}
The '''Zanzibar leopard''' is an [[African leopard]] (''Panthera pardus pardus'') population on [[Unguja|Unguja Island]] in the [[Zanzibar]] archipelago, [[Tanzania]]. It is the island's largest terrestrial [[carnivore]] and [[apex predator]]. In 2008, it was considered [[extinct]] due to persecution by local hunters.<ref name=WalshGoldman08>{{cite journal |author1=Walsh, M.T. |author2=Goldman, H.V. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2008 |title=Updating the Inventory of Zanzibar Leopard Specimens |url=https://www.academia.edu/694088/Updating_the_inventory_of_Zanzibar_leopard_specimens/ |journal=Cat News |volume=49 |pages=4–6}}</ref> Increasing conflict between people and leopards in the 20th century led to their demonization and determined attempts to exterminate them. Efforts to develop a leopard [[conservation biology|conservation]] program in the mid-1990s were shelved when wildlife researchers concluded that there was little prospect for the population's long-term survival.<ref name=Stuart/> However, camera trap footage revealed in 2018 of a similar-looking leopard has renewed hopes for the population's survival, though little information is known.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.insideedition.com/zanzibar-leopard-captured-camera-despite-being-declared-extinct-43962|title=Zanzibar Leopard Captured on Camera, Despite Being Declared Extinct|work=Inside Edition|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en}}</ref>
The Zanzibar leopard was described as a [[leopard]] [[subspecies]] by [[Reginald Innes Pocock]], who proposed the [[scientific name]] ''Panthera pardus adersi'' in 1932.<ref name="Pocock1932">{{cite journal |last1=Pocock|first1=R. I. |date=1932 |title=The Leopards of Africa |url=|journal=Proceedings of the Zoological Society of London|volume=102|issue=2|pages=543–591|doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1932.tb01085.x|via=}}</ref> In 1996, it was subsumed to ''P. p. pardus''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Miththapala |first=S. |author2=Seidensticker, J. |author3=O'Brien, S. J. |year=1996 |title=Phylogeographic Subspecies Recognition in Leopards (''P. pardus''): Molecular Genetic Variation |journal=Conservation Biology |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=1115–1132 | doi=10.1046/j.1523-1739.1996.10041115.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Uphyrkina|first=O. |last2=Johnson |first2=E.W. |last3=Quigley |first3=H. |last4=Miquelle |first4=D. |last5=Marker |first5=L. |last6=Bush |first6=M. |last7=O'Brien |first7=S. J. |year=2001 |title=Phylogenetics, genome diversity and origin of modern leopard, ''Panthera pardus'' |journal=Molecular Ecology |volume=10 |issue=11 |pages=2617–2633 |url=http://www.biosoil.ru/files/00001386.pdf |doi=10.1046/j.0962-1083.2001.01350.x|pmid=11883877}}</ref>
== Evolutionary history == The [[evolution]]ary history of the Zanzibar leopard parallels that of other endemics on Unguja, including the [[Zanzibar servaline genet]] and the [[Zanzibar red colobus]]. It is thought to have evolved in isolation from the African leopard since at least the end of the [[Last glacial period|Ice Age]], when the island was separated from mainland Tanzania by rising [[sea level]]s. The [[founder effect]] and [[adaptation]] to local conditions produced a smaller leopard than its continental relatives and one whose [[rosette (zoology)|rosettes]] have partially disintegrated into spots.<ref name=Pakenham1984>{{cite book | author = Pakenham, R.H.W. | year = 1984 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/14538645/The-Mammals-of-Zanzibar-and-Pemba/ | title = The Mammals of Zanzibar and Pemba Islands | location = Harpenden | publisher = privately printed}}</ref><ref name=Kingdon1989>{{cite book | author = Kingdon, J. | year = 1989 | title = Island Africa: The Evolution of Africa's Rare Animals and Plants | location = Princeton | publisher = [[Princeton University Press]]}}</ref>
== Behavior and Ecology == Very little is known about the Zanzibar leopard's [[behavior]] and ecology.<ref name=Walsh>{{cite journal |author1=Walsh, M.T. |author2=Goldman, H.V. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2003 |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/14568104/The-Zanzibar-Leopard-between-Science-and-Cryptozoology/ |title=The Zanzibar Leopard Between Science and Cryptozoology |journal=Nature East Africa |volume=33 |issue=1/2 |pages=14–16}}</ref> It has never been studied in the wild, and the last sighting of a live leopard happened in the early 1980s.<ref name=Swai1983>Swai, I.S. (1983). ''Wildlife Conservation Status in Zanzibar''. Unpublished M.Sc. dissertation, [[University of Dar es Salaam]].</ref> Most [[zoology|zoologists]] have since presumed the Zanzibar leopard to be extinct or very nearly so.<ref name=Stuart>{{cite book |authors=Stuart, C. & Stuart, T. |year=1997 |title=A Preliminary Faunal Survey of South-eastern Unguja (Zanzibar) with Special Emphasis on the Leopard ''Panthera pardus adersi'' |publisher=African-Arabian Wildlife Research Centre |location=Loxton, South Africa}}</ref>
Only six skins have been located in museums, including the [[type (zoology)|type specimen]] in the [[Natural History Museum, London]], and a much-faded mounted specimen in the [[Zanzibar Museum]].<ref name=WalshGoldman08/> However, Zanzibar government statistics indicate that leopards were still being killed by hunters in the mid-1990s, and islanders continue to report sightings and [[livestock]] [[predation]].<ref name=Goldman2002>{{cite journal |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2002 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13994714/Is-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi-Extinct/ | title = Is the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') Extinct? | journal = Journal of East African Natural History | volume = 91 | issue = 1/2 | pages = 15–25 | doi = 10.2982/0012-8317(2002)91[15:ITZLPP]2.0.CO;2 | issn = 0012-8317}}</ref>
== Extirpation == [[File:Zanzibar Leopard 8.JPG|thumb|Close up of head]] Rural Zanzibaris’ descriptions of the leopard and its habits are characterized by the widespread [[belief]] that a large number of these [[carnivore]]s are kept by [[witchcraft|witches]] and sent by them to harm or otherwise harass villagers. This belief comes together with an elaborate package of ideas about how leopards are bred, trained, exchanged and sent to do the evil bidding of their owners. For local farmers this supplies a neat explanation for [[predation]] by leopards, and more generally for their appearance "out of place" in the vicinity of farms and villages.<ref name=Goldman1997>{{cite web |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1997 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/17317225/A-Leopard-in-Jeopardy-An-Anthropological-Survey-of-Practices-and-Beliefs-which-Threaten-the-Survival-of-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi/ | title = A Leopard in Jeopardy: An Anthropological Survey of Practices and Beliefs which Threaten the Survival of the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') | work = Zanzibar Forestry Technical Paper No. 63, Jozani-Chwaka Bay Conservation Project, Commission for Natural Resources, Zanzibar | accessdate = 2011-05-29}}</ref>
The growth of human [[population]] and [[agriculture]] in the 20th century was largely responsible for this state of affairs, as people encroached on leopard [[habitat (ecology)|habitat]] and prey species. Increasing conflict with leopards and the fear that this generated led to a series of campaigns to exterminate them. These were localized at first, but became island-wide after the [[Zanzibar Revolution]] of 1964, when a combined anti-[[witchcraft]] and leopard-killing campaign was launched under the leadership of a witch-finder.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Walsh| first1=M.T.|last2=Goldman| first2=H.V.|editor1-first=E.| editor1-last=Dounias |editor2-first=E.| editor2-last=Motte-Florac |editor3-first=M.| editor3-last=Dunham|title=Le symbolisme des animaux: L'animal, clef de voûte de la relation entre l'homme et la nature? [Animal symbolism: Animals, keystone of the relationship between man and nature?] |publisher=Éditions de l’IRD |location = Paris|date=2007 |pages=1133–1182 |chapter=Killing the King: The Demonization and Extermination of the Zanzibar Leopard [Tuer le roi: la diabolisation et l’extermination du leopard de Zanzibar] |chapterurl=https://www.scribd.com/doc/14070237/Killing-the-King-The-Demonization-and-Extermination-of-the-Zanzibar-Leopard/ }}</ref> The long-term result of this campaign and the subsequent classification of the leopard as "[[vermin]]" was to bring them to the brink of [[extinction]].<ref name=Walsh/>
== Conservation== Serious attention was not paid to the Zanzibar leopard's plight until the mid-1990s, by which time some authorities were already listing it as extinct.<ref name=Nowell>{{cite book |author1=Nowell, K. |author2=Jackson, P. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1996 | url = http://www.carnivoreconservation.org/files/actionplans/wildcats.pdf/ | title = Wild Cats: Status Survey and Conservation Action Plan | location = Gland, Switzerland | publisher = [[IUCN]]}}</ref> A leopard conservation program was drafted by the [[CARE (relief)|CARE]]-funded Jozani-Chwaka Bay Conservation Project, but abandoned in 1997 when wildlife researchers failed to find evidence for the leopard's continuing presence in and around [[Jozani forest]].<ref name=Stuart/>
Local wildlife officials, however, remained more optimistic about the leopard's survival, and some Zanzibaris have proposed approaching alleged leopard keepers in order to ask them to display their leopards to paying visitors. Villagers sometimes offer to take tourists or researchers to see "domesticated" leopards in return for cash, but so far none of these "kept leopard chases" has been known to end in a successful sighting.<ref name=Swai1983/><ref name=Marshall>Marshall, S. (1994). ''The Status of the Zanzibar Leopard''. SIT Tanzania & Commission for Natural Resources, Zanzibar.</ref><ref name=Selkow>Selkow, B. (1995). ''A Survey of Villager Perceptions of the Zanzibar Leopard''. SIT Tanzania & Commission for Natural Resources, Zanzibar.</ref>
These conflicting perceptions of the Zanzibar leopard's status and the possibility of its conservation have yet to be reconciled, presenting a dilemma that has been highlighted by researchers.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2007 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13986864/HumanWildlife-Conflict-Unequal-Knowledge-and-the-Failure-to-Conserve-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi/ | title = Human-Wildlife Conflict, Unequal Knowledge and the Failure to Conserve the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') | work = Poster presented to the Felid Biology and Conservation Conference, Wildlife Conservation Research Unit (WildCRU), University of Oxford, 17–21 September 2007 | accessdate = 2009-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Goldman, H.V. |author2=Walsh, M.T. |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 2008 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13986833/When-Culture-Threatens-the-Conservation-of-Biological-Diversity-The-Tragic-Case-of-the-Zanzibar-Leopard-Panthera-pardus-adersi/ | title = When Culture Threatens the Conservation of Biological Diversity: The Tragic Case of the Zanzibar Leopard (''Panthera pardus adersi'') | work = Poster presented to Sustaining Cultural and Biological Diversity in a Rapidly Changing World: Lessons for Global Policy, Thirteenth Annual Symposium of the Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, American Museum of Natural History, New York, 2–5 April 2008 | accessdate = 2009-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Walsh | first1 = M.T. | last2 = Goldman | first2 = H.V. | year = 2012 | title = Chasing Imaginary Leopards: Science, Witchcraft and the Politics of Conservation in Zanzibar | journal = Journal of Eastern African Studies | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 727–746 | doi = 10.1080/17531055.2012.729778 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Walsh|first=M.T.|last2=Goldman|first2=H.V.|date=|year=2017|title=Cryptids and credulity: The Zanzibar leopard and other imaginary beings|url=https://www.taylorfrancis.com/books/e/9781317180463/chapters/10.4324/9781315567297-11|journal=Anthropology and Cryptozoology: Exploring Encounters with Mysterious Creatures|language=en|publisher=Routledge|publication-place=London|volume=|pages=54–90|doi=10.4324/9781315567297}}</ref>
==Possible survival== In 2018, a camera trap, placed for an [[Animal Planet]] show called ''Extinct or Alive'', caught apparent footage of a leopard on Unguja Island. The leopard appeared smaller than leopards from the mainland, and seemed to have smaller, more solid spots than normally seen on African leopards. Further investigations are planned in order to confirm whether or not this is a Zanzibar leopard, and whether a viable population still exists.<ref name=":0" />
